arm_group.description: Assessment   of experimental pain models before and after treatment
Assessment   of experimental pain models before and after treatment

brief_summary.textblock:
The aims of this study were to assess the effects of the dopamine agonist apomorphine on
      experimental pain models in healthy subjects and to explore the possible association between
      these effects and a common polymorphism within the dopamine transporter gene.

detailed_description.textblock:
Healthy volunteers (n=105) participated in this randomized double-blind, placebo-controlled,
      cross-over trial. Heat pain threshold and intensity, cold pain threshold, and the response
      to tonic cold pain (latency, intensity, and tolerance) were evaluated before and for up to
      120 min after the administration of 1.5 mg apomorphine/placebo. A polymorphism (DAT-1)
      within the dopamine transporter gene (SLC6A3) was investigated.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

        - healthy and free from chronic pain of any type did not use any medications other than
        oral contraceptives were able to understand the purpose and instructions of the study.

        Exclusion Criteria:

        - any type of medical or painful condition use of medications or recreational drugs
        pregnancy.

clinical_study.official_title: Alterations in the Ability to Tolerate Experimental Pain by Apomorphine and Its Association With a Dopamine Transporter Polymorphism

overall_official.affiliation: Rambam Health Care Campus, Haifa, Israel

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Basic Science
